text: (light music)
- Welcome to Conversations with Leaders.
My name is Miriam McLemore
and I'm an Enterprise Strategist with AWS.

I am thrilled today to
have the opportunity
to speak with Bryson Koehler.
Bryson is the CTO of Equifax.
Bryson, welcome.
- It's so great to be here.
Good to see you.
- Yeah, so good to see you.

Hey, Bryson, could you
give us a little bit

of your background and
your role at Equifax?
- So, I'm a geek at heart.

I have loved technology
since I was eight years old

and have really spent my
career helping companies

leverage technology to
transform who they are,

how they work, and
achieve better outcomes.
And my role at Equifax as the CTO

is I lead our technology
and product organizations,

and look after all of the
things that we are doing
across our landscape of technology,
and all of our products globally

to help Equifax continue
its journey forward.
- Now, you joined Equifax, what, 2018?
- I joined in 2018.
So, I've been here three years.
- Great, so you joined at kind of,

I'm an Atlanta native, kind
of a tough time for Equifax.
Could you tell us a little bit about that?

- So, I love hard problems.
- Yeah (laughing).

- As good engineers do,
the harder the problem,
the more exciting.

I joined shortly after Mark
Begor, our CEO, joined.

And signed up to help
reinvent the company,

and really bring back
trust to our customers
and to our consumers.
To make sure that people would entrust
their most precious data with Equifax
because we are a data company and we are
a decision intelligence company.
And so if we don't have trust in terms
of how we collect data, how we store data,

how there's the right
permissible use on data,

and how that governance trail
follows data end-to-end,
then we won't be able to continue to solve

and make better decisions
with our customers.
And so, that's why I joined,

was to help use technology
to put Equifax on that track.

- Now, not all of our
listeners may know the issue
that Equifax experienced that so many
companies have experienced.

Could you share?
- So in the summer of 2017,

Equifax experienced a data
security breach by a state actor.

And so as very sophisticated
attack on the company
that really helped galvanize the company

around a transformation of
itself, how it operated,

how it thought about technology,
but not just technology;
the culture, the people, our products,

really the full end-to-end
working of how Equifax operated.

- Now, you did probably
have choices though

on you guys have gone
aggressively toward cloud.

- Yes.
- But you could have just
kind of holed up and invested-

- Yeah.
- Internally.

- So, when I arrived,
we had a stated course

of patching to currency.
- Right.
- Just making sure we got our systems
to the right level of maintenance.
And my reflection working with Mark

and the rest of the Senior
Leadership Team was that

that was really missing an
opportunity to set Equifax up
for a sustainable future.

It's one thing to invest to
get to where you need to be,

but it's another thing to
make sure you're setting
the company up for sustainability.

The cloud really enables
an evergreen mindset
of always being current,
and really changing the culture to embrace
a destroy and deploy mindset.
So that you're always on the latest.

- Yep.
- And that really would

set the company up, not
for just getting good
at a moment in time, but staying good.
We wanted to be a leader in security.

And to do that, to be
a leader in security,

you have to be making sure
that the engineering practices,
the discipline that you put in place,

the repeatability of your
software engineering,
the deployment, you have to bake that in.
And you can't bolt it on to the end.
And then, further, the opportunity for us
to really rethink our data,

to really be able to
bring our data together,
to remove some of the constraints
that a legacy mindset will hold.
Being able to bring that data together,

leveraging the infinite
horizontal scalability
the public cloud provides,

gives us the ability now
to bring our data together,

leverage best of read
encryption capabilities,
leverage the compute capabilities of cloud

to really provide an end-to-end
view of data governance,

and solve problems that we
couldn't solve in the old way.

And that cloud-native mindset
was not a lift and shift.

It was not a let's go
take all of the silos

of things we have and just
move its hosting location

from a legacy on-prem
data center to cloud.
It was really a mindset that said,

we really need to rethink
who we are and rebuild.
And we've done that.

We have about two applications
that we decommission
for every one application we've rebuilt.

Which shows you that product
rationalization mindset

that we've been able to
achieve as we go through this.
So every time we rebuild an application,
we're able to shut two down.

That's led to being able to
shut down 12 data centers so far

which really continues to help
us on that journey of kind of

getting rid of the old,
not just moving it,
but getting rid of it and rebuilding
in a cloud-native mindset.

- Absolutely, now your
customers are probably in lots

of different places, as far as
their adoption of technology.

What are you guys doing
to help your customers

on this journey so they can
leverage all the new products
that you are able to deliver to them?

- You know, so, we are a
highly regulated business.
And as we started this journey,

it took a lot of conversations
around how we would

be better off doing this
migration into public cloud
than we would be staying on-prem.

Building that trust, and
that was through a lot

of very technical, detailed,
architectural conversations.
A lot of show and tell,

and then prove.
- Yeah, yeah.

- And that turned from, I
think, disbelief in some cases,
to invitations to come back to help.

So it turned from "Bryson,
we're not really sure,"
to "Hey, could you and your team come back

because we now believe we
are behind on our journey
and you guys are ahead.
Could you help us?"
And that was really inspiring for the team
because you went from kind of feeling like

maybe we were behind.
- Right.
- To now, we were being respected
by our customers as leaders.

- Well, and it's terrific as
someone who spends her day

talking to customers about
the journey to cloud,
and how you accomplished that.

I think having a leader and
a case study like you built
at Equifax is so important,
particularly to financial services,
but to so many companies.
- So there's a lot of great companies
that leverage the cloud.

But I think Equifax is
in a different league

with the fact that we
are a global company,

we operate in 26 countries
and we're highly regulated.
We're highly regulated by regulators
in all of those countries.

And that is a different
technical challenge to solve.

And I think as we have solved
that with close to 90,000
customers migrating so far,
and every day putting new workloads on
and migrating those revenue streams over,

giving us 12 data centers
that we've shut down so far

of our legacy estate,
that builds confidence

in the financial services
industry and beyond

that the cloud really
is the place to solve
their most difficult technical challenges.
- So, you're now kind of there.
What can you do today for customers
that was very challenging to do before?

If you were gonna sell this
in to a customer and say,
"Okay, now we can..."

- Yeah, so we've still got
some final mile work to do,

but we've seen record
new product innovations
and launches as a company.

You know, we've launched
more new products last year,

even with everything
going on in the world,

than at any point in
Equifax's history ever.

And I think that's fantastic.
- Yeah.

- And I think that's a testament
to the speed of innovation
that the cloud enables.
So instead of asking Equifax,

"Hey, Equifax, what do
you know about Bryson?"
And getting lots of different answers.

- Right.
- I can now respond back
with a complete 360 view.

And so, our teams in Australia,
the teams here in the US,
have launched new innovative reports
and scores and capabilities,

whether those are through
traditional delivery mechanisms
or through APIs, they give that 360 view.

That's really bringing a
bunch of attributes about me

together and the right
use, at the right time,

with the right governance,
at the right speed,
that we couldn't do before.
And now, we're able to innovate.

We're doing 160ish, maybe
165 production builds a day-

- Wow.
- Across Equifax.

So if you think about that
kind of CI/CD pipeline-
- From what?
- From maybe one a week, maybe.

- Right.
- Right, so one a week,

to 160 plus a day.
- A day, right.
- Massive velocity improvements.

And I think we're just
getting started on that.
And that helps us, as you know,

to lower risk.
- Yep.

- And improve customer
satisfaction and keep us safer.

Because every time we deploy
being on the latest image,
being on the latest build,

leveraging the latest-
- Right.

- That's all a part of
building security in
versus bolting it on.

And so all of those things
demonstrate things we weren't
able to easily do before.

- Now, that also was a
massive technology change,

but cultural change.
- Yeah.

- Right, 'cause there
were people that I'm sure

that were used to getting
a report a certain way
or having something work a certain way.

How did you go down the
cultural transformation?

- So, I think that this is
more of a people journey
than it is a technology one.
With partners like Amazon,

we don't have to build or
invent a lot of technology.

- Right.
- Right, like we're not
inventing a lot of technology.

We're inventing ways
to use the technology.

- Right.
- Inventing ways
to leverage the capabilities.

We're unique in how we have
stitched things together.
How we've thought about deploying
that in a highly automated, secure way.

That's all true.
- Yep.

- It enabled us to turn our
attention to the people side.

So we're a large technology
and product organization,
FTEs and contractors around the world,

we were over 8,500 at the
peak of our transformation.

That's a lot of people to
make sure that we're aligned

on where we're going.
- Yeah.
- And so, we built an engineering handbook

which was basically our Bible
around what we believed,
our philosophy around technology,
our philosophy around the processes.

And all of our people read
it, we take a test on it,
we make sure that we're living by it,

we grade ourselves on how
well teams are living by it.

We've got over 750 cloud certified
engineers now at Equifax.

- Oh, that's great.
- Which is fantastic.
- [Miriam] Yeah.

- And we've refreshed a good
portion of the team as well;
bringing in new mindset where people

who have done this before-
- Right.
- Can help teach those who haven't.

And as a leader, I always
say, I look for three things,
or to do three things.
One, I want you to love what you do.

- Yeah.
- Two, I wanna set you
up for success.

And three, I wanna make
you more employable.
And part of making you more employable
was teaching you the skills.

And the technology skills
of cloud are not just
the technical skills.

It's the way of working.
- So, I love that.

Bryson, thank you so much for
spending time with us today,

and your insights.
- You bet.

It was great to see you.
- Great to see you.
(light music)
